title: WESTERN (R): Germany (RG). Church and state in GDR (FO371-172203).

Germany
format: 1 online resource : colour text file, PDF
description: A file of correspondence and reports concerning religious developments in East Germany. The documents discuss an article published in the East German press assessing the contribution of East German Christians to "the realisation of socialism"; and the East German authorities' attack on the Saxon branch of the Confessional Church for circulating seven theses dealing with the church's position in East Germany. The documents also cover a visit to East Germany by a delegation from the American Friends Service Committee (A.F.S.C.), a Quaker organisation, at the invitation of the East German Peace Council; the delegation's meeting with Walter Ulbricht, the East German leader; and the possibility of the A.F.S.C. and the Peace Council working together to promote the "relaxation and elimination of international tension". Other documents comment on recent developments in the Evangelical Church in East Germany, with one branch publishing a thesis banning its officials from working in politics.

abstract: A file of correspondence and reports concerning religious developments in East Germany. The documents discuss an article published in the East German press assessing the contribution of East German Christians to "the realisation of socialism"; and the East German authorities' attack on the Saxon branch of the Confessional Church for circulating seven theses dealing with the church's position in East Germany. The documents also cover a visit to East Germany by a delegation from the American Friends Service Committee (A.F.S.C.), a Quaker organisation, at the invitation of the East German Peace Council; the delegation's meeting with Walter Ulbricht, the East German leader; and the possibility of the A.F.S.C. and the Peace Council working together to promote the "relaxation and elimination of international tension". Other documents comment on recent developments in the Evangelical Church in East Germany, with one branch publishing a thesis banning its officials from working in politics.
